awd_titl_txt: Understanding the protein composition and dynamics of the nuclear envelope in plants
awd_abstract_narration:
The nuclear envelope (NE) isolates and organizes the genome. It selectively accumulates proteins that carry out vital cellular functions and represents the hallmark of eukaryotic cells. Despite the increased appreciation of the NE as a crucial structural and signaling platform, knowledge on the composition and function of NE proteins is limited, particularly in plants, which significantly limits our understanding of plant NE function and its critical influence on various aspects of plant physiology and cell biology. This project aims to assemble the inventory of NE membrane proteins in the model organism Arabidopsis as a critical step towards a comprehensive understanding of the plant NE constituents and functions. In addition, this project will investigate molecular mechanisms that regulate the NE protein homeostasis through specialized proteolytic system. This research will generate valuable NE-associated protein databases and innovative protein identification tools for the plant and NE biology research community and deeply engage STEM and URM undergraduates in cutting-edge training in genetics, proteomics, cell biology, and molecular biology.

Recent studies discovered a range of novel plant NE components and their significance in diverse biological processes, providing new insights into conserved eukaryotic NE functions as well as NE-associated mechanisms unique to plants. This project will deploy the newly developed proximity labeling technology coupled with label-free quantitative mass spectrometry to make rapid advances in establishing a precise and comprehensive view of the protein landscape in the plant NE. Using a combined genetic, proteomic, and cell biological approach, this project will also define key regulatory components of a newly identified inner nuclear membrane-associated protein degradation pathway that is critical in maintaining the NE function, adding a new branch to the organelle-specific membrane-associated proteolytic system in higher eukaryotes. This research promises to significantly advance our understanding of fundamental biological principles underlying the nuclear membrane and nuclear function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our cells each contain a protected central compartment called the nucleus, which houses our genetic material (DNA). The nucleus is enclosed by a double-layered barrier called the nuclear envelope, which acts like a sophisticated control center for the cell. This barrier does more than just protect our DNA—it helps determine how genes are used and coordinates the exchange of information between the nucleus and the surrounding cell interior. Even though researchers have studied the nuclear envelope extensively in humans and yeast, our understanding of this crucial cellular structure remains incomplete. Moreover, we know very little about how the nuclear envelope works in other organisms, particularly in plants, which have evolved unique nuclear features to survive in challenging environments.

In this NSF-funded research project, we studied the nuclear envelope in an organism named Arabidopsis thaliana. This plant serves as an excellent model to understand both the basic functions of the nuclear envelope that are shared across many eukaryotic species and the special adaptations that plants have developed. During the funding period, our research made significant progress in three main areas:

1. Mapping the Complex Gateway into the Cell Nucleus: Our focus is to understand the nuclear pore complex—a mega protein assembly that forms channels through the nuclear envelope. These channels control what molecules can enter and exit the nucleus, functioning like sophisticated security checkpoints. Using advanced research techniques, including proximity labeling, multi-omics, biochemistry, cell biology, and AI-assisted modeling, we created the first complete map of all proteins associated with nuclear pores in any living organism. Our analysis revealed an unprecedented complexity in this structure, which harbors over 500 distinct protein species—far exceeding previous estimates. This investigation uncovered that nuclear pores extend beyond their canonical role as transport channels, functioning as sophisticated hubs that orchestrate the flow of genetic information from DNA to proteins. The pores achieve this by creating specialized microenvironments that concentrate diverse molecular machinery, including chromatin remodelers, transcriptional regulators, mRNA processing factors, and translation machinery. This spatial organization represents an elegant evolutionary solution by eukaryotic cells to coordinate the key steps of the Central Dogma.

2. Defining Novel Functions of the Nuclear Transport System: While nuclear pores act as gateways within the nuclear envelope, specialized proteins called karyopherins serve as molecular transporters, shuttling macromolecules in and out of the nucleus. In a surprising discovery, we found that these transport proteins in plants do more than just move cargo—they also act as molecular caretakers (chaperons), preventing certain protein-RNA complexes from clumping inappropriately. We found this chaperoning activity is particularly important for preventing autoimmune induction in plants by suppressing abnormal aggregation of a key splicing regulatory complex. The evolutionary significance of this mechanism is underscored by parallel findings in human cells, where karyopherins prevent pathological aggregation of RNA-binding proteins—a process implicated in various neurodegenerative disorders. This discovery illuminates a previously unrecognized yet evolutionarily conserved function of nuclear transport proteins, highlighting their fundamental role in maintaining cellular homeostasis and preventing diseases. 

3. Comprehensive Profiling of Plant Nuclear Envelope Components: To understand the protein composition and function of the plant nuclear envelope, we conducted a comprehensive survey of nuclear envelope-associated proteins using advanced proximity labeling proteomics. We identified over 700 distinct proteins—establishing a detailed molecular atlas that illuminates both the architecture of plant nuclear organization and its evolutionary relationship to other eukaryotes. This extensive catalog serves as a foundational resource for researchers investigating nuclear dynamics and plant cell biology. A key discovery emerging from this work was PNET2, a conserved protein that orchestrates three-dimensional chromatin organization at the nuclear periphery. Anchored to the inner nuclear envelope, PNET2 modulates perinuclear chromatin architecture and genome activity, thereby mediating the crucial balance between plant growth and stress adaptation. Beyond revealing fundamental principles of genome organization at the nuclear periphery, our work uncovered a sophisticated quality control mechanism that eliminates damaged membrane proteins from the nuclear envelope. This finding carries particular biomedical relevance, as the accumulation of such damaged proteins has been implicated in various hereditary disorders and developmental abnormalities.

Broader Impact: This project's impact extends beyond its scientific discoveries. We provided comprehensive research training opportunities for a diverse group of 21 scientists at different career stages, including 12 women and 5 individuals from underrepresented minority groups. This investment has already shown results: two postdoctoral researchers have started their own research groups as principal investigators, eight graduate and undergraduate students received prestigious fellowships or competitive awards, and at least five undergraduate students have pursued advanced degrees in biology and medical fields.

Key results and datasets generated through this project have been made publicly available, fostering collaboration and accelerating discoveries in nuclear envelope biology. Educational materials derived from the findings have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate curricula, enhancing teaching and learning by making complex concepts accessible to students with diverse academic backgrounds.
